four 
The  Road  Network  Development  Project  1  comprises 
components: (i) construction, (ii) ancillary and emergency works, (iii) 
maintenance,  and  (iv)  business  process  development.  The  main 
activity of the first component is construction of a 143-kilometer (km), 
two-lane  road  from  Bala  Murghab  to  Leman,  which  is  part  of  the 
critical missing link of the Ring Road1. The ancillary and emergency 
works component will allow rapid reconstruction and rehabilitation of 
critical  road  infrastructure  that  have  been  damaged  due  to  the 
continuing  conflict  or  designed  at  suboptimal  levels  for  construction 
under  emergency  conditions.  It  is  a  cost-effective  mechanism  of 
providing financing for uncertain and unprogrammed works. 
 
The maintenance component will help ensure sustainability of ADB’s 
previous road investment in Afghanistan by facilitating performance-
based  maintenance  on  at  least  1,000  km  of  roads.  The  business 
process development component will help increase the road network 
management  capacity  of  the  Ministry  of  Public  Works  (MPW) 
through  (i)  project  support  through  specialists  on  maintenance 
contract administration, bridge and pavement management, right-of-
way  preservation,  and  environmental  management;  and 
(ii) 
implementation  of  a  management  information  system  (MIS).  Taken 
together,  the  four  components  of  the  Project  will  increase  overall 
benefits to road users and communities in Afghanistan. 
 
Due  to  the  terrain  and  the  pattern  of  human  settlement,  road 
transport  is  the  only  technically  and  economically  feasible  mode  of 
transport in many parts of Afghanistan. Since 2002, the international 
community has provided nearly $2 billion to improve and pave 96% 
of the regional road network (the Ring Road and links from it to the 
international  borders)  and  35%  of  the  national  road  network  (roads 
connecting  provincial  capitals).  ADB  has  contributed  $429  million 
towards  this.  However,  without  the  road  from  Bala  Murghab  to

Leman, the Ring Road is unable to fully perform its intended role as 
the  backbone  of  the  national  transportation  system  and  principal 
conduit for national and international passenger and freight traffic. In 
total,  nearly  $3  billion  is  required  to  repair  or  construct  the  key 
components  of  the  34,000  km  road  network,  including  the  Bala 
Murghab–Leman road. To that end, the international community has 
pledged  approximately  $1  billion  over  the  next  3  years,  but 
Afghanistan needs a further $2 billion to provide a minimum level of 
nationwide mobility. 
 
Most donors, including ADB, procured civil works on road projects on 
a  design-build  basis.  While  this  method  of  procurement  has 
expedited implementation, it has also required design variations. The 
continuing  conflict  has  resulted  in  increased  material  prices  and 
damaged  road  assets.  These  conditions  have  created  several 
financial challenges for MPW, contractors, and consultants, and the 
need for nontraditional financing mechanisms.  
 
The total annual cost of maintenance of the regional road network is 
expected to increase from about $6 million in 2007 to approximately 
$25  million  by  2012.  At  the  2006  London  Conference  Afghanistan2 
agreed  to  establish  a  financially  sustainable  road  maintenance 
program  by  the  end  of  2007.  However,  in  the  absence  of  a  reliable 
basis of cost recovery, financial assistance from donors is needed to 
implement  a  systematic  preventative  maintenance  program  and 
preserve the value of past and future road investment.  
 
Several critical gaps in the Government’s business process constrain 
the  implementation  of  an  efficient  program  of  investment  and 
maintenance. These gaps, which are exacerbated by the human and 
operating resource constraints, must be bridged with technology and 
knowledge transfer.  
 
The  Project  will  contribute  to  the  growth  of  Afghanistan’s  domestic 
and international trade. The main outcomes of the Project will be (i) 
higher  levels  of  mobility  and  the  supply  of  intercity,  interprovincial, 
and  international  transport  services;  (ii)  increased  levels  of  service 
on  critical  road  sections;  and  (iii)  an  increase  in  service  life  of  the 
regional road network. 
 
The  investment  cost  of  the  Project  is  estimated  at  $180  million 
equivalent, including taxes and duties. 
 

Afghanistan  has  requested  ADB  to  help  finance  part  of  its  road 
investment  program  through  a  grant  in  the  amount  of  up  to  $176 
million from ADB’s Special Funds resources.

The  works  supervision  consultants  will  collect  baseline  data  on 
physical  components  of  the  Project  through  consultations  with  local 
communities,  field  observations,  and  measurements.  MPW  will 
collect  baseline  data  on  nonphysical  components.  The  collection  of 
data will continue during implementation of the Project, and data will 
be  analyzed  every  12  months.  Results  of  the  analyses,  and 
corrective  measures  (if  any)  taken  will  be  reported  in  MPW’s 
quarterly progress report following the analyses.  
 
MPW  will  also  perform  a  complete  analysis  of  related  primary  and 
secondary  data  on  impacts  and  outcomes  within  1  month  of 
completion  of  the  Project.  The  results  of  that  analysis  will  be 
contained in the Recipient’s project completion report to ADB, which 
will be submitted within 3 months of completion of the Project.  
 
Goods  and  works  financed  from  the  grant  will  be  procured  in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended 
from  time  to  time).  Consulting  services  from  firms  and  individual 
experts will be procured according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Specific 
procedures  have  been  agreed  between  ADB  and  MPW  and  are 
outlined in the procurement plan (Appendix 8). The procurement plan 
will  be  updated  at  least  annually  covering  the  next  18  months  of 
procurement activity. 
 
ADB  has  approved  advance  contracting  and  retroactive  financing 
from the grant for expenditure incurred on eligible works, goods, and 
consulting  services,  procured  in  accordance  with  the  Procurement 
Guidelines  and  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  Afghanistan 
acknowledges  that  any  concurrence  by  ADB  with  the  procedures, 
documentation,  or  proposal  for  award  does  not  commit  ADB  to 
finance such expenses.  
 
After the Bala Murghab–Leman road is completed, the overall travel 
time  between  the  northeast  and  southwest  of  Afghanistan  will 
decrease  by  at  least  30%.  The  investment  under  the  ancillary  and 
emergency works component will increase average journey speed by 
20  percent  over 
  The 
maintenance  component  of  the  Project  will  increase  the  service  life 
of roads. Taken together, the components will lower transport costs, 
allow  people  and  goods  to  move  faster  and  less  expensively,  and 
help sustain economic returns and personal mobility. Additionally, as 
the  road  will  be  used  to  gain  faster  access  to  Persian  Gulf  and 
Caspian Sea ports, the components will also generate regional traffic 
in neighboring states.  
 
Construction  and  maintenance  work  under  the  Project  will  increase 
business  opportunities  for  national contractors and  consultants,  and 
employment  opportunities  in  project  areas  during  implementation 
and  operation.  The  related  roads  and  off-road  service  areas  will

The  Ministry  of  Transport  and  Civil  Aviation  (MOTCA)  sets 
passenger  fares  and  freight  tariffs,  and  these  impede  the  growth  in 
the  number  of  passenger  and  freight  service-providers  who  can 
benefit from the reductions in travel time and offer higher frequency 
of service to users. ADB is currently providing technical assistance to 
MOTCA for reforming the regulations, which will lead to the removal 
of  barriers  to  entry  and  operation  in  the  freight  and  passenger 
service market.

I.  

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1.  
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan for the Road Network Development Project 1. The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

1. 

Infrastructure and Services 

Performance Indicators and Analysis  

 
A.  
 
 
 
Because  of  the  terrain  and  the  pattern  of  human  settlement,  road  transport  is  the  only 
2. 
technically  and  economically  feasible  mode  of  transport  in  many  parts  of  Afghanistan.  Until  a 
road development program was initiated under the first 5-Year Development Plan (1956–1961), 
even national and international road traffic used one or more of the dirt tracks in the ancient Silk 
Road and Spice Road corridors. The Soviet Union and United States provided financial aid for 
this  program,  which  helped  build  1,900  kilometers  (km)  of  paved  roads,  including  parts  of  the 
present regional road network. Emphasis on roads was retained in the second and third 5-year 
development  plans,  and  another  600  km  of  road  were  added  to  the  regional  road  network 
between 1965 and 1975. By 1980, more than half the country’s population lived within 50 km of 
the  regional  network.  In  1982  27%  of  development  funds  were  allocated  to  transport  and 
communications, and the length of paved roads in the regional road network increased to 2,900 
km.  However,  there  were  no  attempts  to  develop  secondary  and  tertiary  roads  to  link  rural 
communities to the paved roads, or to one another. Because of this neglect, interprovincial and 
intraprovincial travel was difficult, and even the famine of 1971 was more serious because food 
could not quickly be transported to the provinces in need.3  
 
In  the  two  decades  since  1980,  70%  of  transport  infrastructure,  including  the  Ring 
3. 
Road4,  was  damaged  by  the  different  warring  factions,  or  deteriorated  in  the  absence  of 
maintenance.5 According to the Ministry of Public Works (MPW), even today less than 10% of 
the country’s 35,000 km of official roads6 are paved and 40% of the roads are unusable during 
winter  months.  The  Ring  Road  is  the  road  that  links  the  major  cities  of  Afghanistan,  and  it 
remains  the  backbone  of  the  national  transportation  system  and  the  principal  conduit  for 
national and international passenger and freight traffic.  
 
Since  2002,  many  primary  roads  have  been  rehabilitated  and  repaired.  In  addition, 
4. 
nearly  1,500  km  of  the  4,900  km  national  (secondary)  road  network,  and  several  thousand 
kilometers of tertiary roads, all with gravel surfaces, have been improved. By June 2007, about 
2,500 km of the original 2,900 km of paved regional road network7 had been reconstructed or 
rehabilitated  to  national  standards  and  paved  with  asphalt  concrete.  Rehabilitation  of  the

 2 

 

remainder,  and  construction  of  approximately  300  km  of  new  roads,  are  expected  to  create  a 
fully paved all-weather regional road network by the end of 2010.  
 
5. 
Provision of freight transport services, which was handed over in the 1970s to a state-
owned  enterprise  with  a  fleet  of  almost  14,000  trucks,  is  now  entirely  in  the  hands  of  private 
operators.  Most  are  owner-operators  offering  informal  services  using  two-  and  three-axle 
vehicles  procured  or  received  from  the  former  state  enterprise.  Also,  private  operators  under 
license  from  the  Ministry  of  Transport  and  Civil  Aviation  (MOTCA)  provide  all  public  transport 
services.  About  165  long-distance  private  bus  operators  are  licensed  by  MOTCA,  and  about 
60%  of  these  are  based  in  Kabul.  These  operators  own  about  14,000  vehicles,  mostly 
minibuses  and  six-  and  eight-seater  vans.  With  the  exception  of  an  informal  bus  service  from 
Jalalabad to Peshawar in Pakistan, there are no passenger or freight transport through-services 
to  neighboring  countries.  According  to  MOTCA,  about  45  million  passengers  travel  within  the 
country each year.  
 
6. 
MOTCA  sets  separate  passenger  fares  and  freight  rates  chargeable  by  operators  for 
services on paved roads and gravel roads.8 In addition to an annual vehicle license fee, MOTCA 
charges each passenger and freight transport vehicle a road usage fee based on the total fares 
collected by the operator or the value of the consignment carried on each trip.9 Private vehicle 
owners  are  required  to  pay  an  annual  license  fee  and  purchase  a  monthly  permit  for  use  of 
certain key roads. While the annual licenses and monthly permits must be pre-purchased at an 
MOTCA  office,  road  usage  fees  must  be  paid  to  MOTCA  officials  at  the  boundaries  before 
entering a city or a province. According to MOTCA, revenue in 2006 from the operational fees 
was  $3  million  compared  to  the  expected  total  revenue  of  $7  million  based  on  traffic  counts 
conducted for the road improvement master plan study.10
 
7. 
MOTCA is responsible for planning, designing, operating, and maintaining the 43 official 
airports in the country, four of which meet International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) class 
4  standards.11  According  to  the  Afghanistan  Compact,12  Kabul  International  Airport  and  Herat 
Airport  will  achieve  full  ICAO  compliance.  Mazar-i-Sharif,  Jalalabad,  and  Kandahar  will  be 
upgraded  with  runway  repairs  and  air  navigation,  fire  and  rescue,  and  communications 
equipment,  and  another  seven  domestic  airports  will  be  upgraded  to  facilitate  domestic  air 
services.  In  2005  Kabul  airport  served  approximately  500,000  domestic  and  international 
passengers.  
 
8. 
Domestic  air  services  between  Kabul  and  selected  major  cities  are  provided  by  the 
state-owned  carrier,  two  privately  owned  Afghan  carriers,  and  UN  humanitarian  operations. 
Frequency to most cities, with the exception of Kandahar, is less than three times a week. Air 
services between Kabul and several European and Asian destinations are provided by Afghan 
as well as regional airlines. At present, only Dubai and New Delhi are international destinations 
with daily flights from Kabul, which carries about 1% of freight and passenger traffic.

roads.

 3 

Railways are limited to two lines: one which connects Toraghondi with Turkmenistan (10 
9. 
km) and the other connecting Naibabad13 with Uzbekistan (16 km). There are about 1,200 km of 
navigable  waters,  mostly  on  the  Amu  Darya  river,  which  can  accommodate  cargo  vessels  of 
about  500  deadweight  tons.  Port  infrastructure  would  need  substantial  investment  before  the 
waterways could become part of the national transportation system.  
 
10. 
The river ports of Hairatan and Shir Khan Bandar reportedly handled about 400,000 tons 
of  Afghanistan’s  trade  with  the  Soviet  Union  in  1981  (footnote  3).  Shir  Khan  Bandar  is  now 
served by a passenger ferry service (three to four times per day) operated by a nongovernment 
organization (Ahmad Shah Massod Foundation) and a three- to five-times daily cargo service of 
powered  barges  operated  by  the  Tajikistan  government.  The  cargo  ferry  carries  4-12  trucks 
hauling  scrap  metal  and  gas,  and  bulk  cargo  (mostly  fertilizer)  from  Tajikistan  to  Afghanistan, 
amounting to about 20 or 25 truck-equivalent loads. About 25 trucks in each direction and 4-5 
trains  with  an  average  of  30  wagons  cross  the  border  between  Uzbekistan  and  Afghanistan 
each day at Hairatan. The service frequency from Turkmenistan to Toraghondi is once every 2 
days  and  each  train  consists  of  about  25  wagons.  More  details  of  the  transport  sector  are  in 
Appendix 2.  
 

2.  

Road Sector Administration, Planning, and Financing 

 
11.  MPW is charged with planning, design, construction, and maintenance of the entire road 
network.  It  has  a  workforce  of  about  100  engineers  and  technical  staff,  and  2,900  laborers 
distributed  among  headquarters  divisions  and  six  regional  offices.  Since  road  construction  at 
present  is  mainly  financed  by  donor  agencies,  MPW  functions  mainly  as  an  administrator  of 
projects. Most construction works, consulting services, and goods for the projects are procured 
through competitive bidding according to national and donor procedures. Routine maintenance 
is  performed  by  MPW  using  force-account  (departmental  workforce)  labor  and  equipment 
assigned to its regional offices.  
 
 To  guide  investment,  Afghanistan  has  prepared  a  road  improvement  master  plan 
12. 
(footnote 7) outlining investment priorities based on strategic and economic goals of the country. 
The  development  partners  have  accepted  the master  plan  and  the  national  road development 
strategy is based on it.  
 
13. 
Compared  with  approximately  $40  million  under  the  first  5-Year  Development  Plan 
(1956–1961),  donors  have  contributed  approximately  $2.2  billion  between  2002  and  2006  for 
regional and national road rehabilitation and reconstruction. Up to the end of 2006, almost 42% 
of  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  investment  in  Afghanistan  has  been  in  transport  and 
communications.  Most of this investment, which at the end of 2006 amounted to $420 million, 
has  been  in  regional  and  national  road  rehabilitation  projects  (see  Appendix  3).  The  total 
physical output of the projects is about 1,000 km of improved regional roads, including 900 km 
of  the  Ring  Road.  These  projects  have  substantially  increased  the  mobility  level  in  northern 
Afghanistan.  Traffic  volumes  on  recently  completed  sections  of  roads  have  grown  at  much 
higher rates than estimated at appraisal.  
 
14. 
Capacity  development  of  road  sector  institutions  has  been  the  mainstay  of  ADB’s 
nonphysical investment in the sector. ADB has provided $7.5 million of technical assistance for 
training  MPW  staff  and  managing  projects.  Such  support  has  helped  lessen  implementation

safeguards and international best practices.  
 
B.  
 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1.  

Development Problems  

largely  unsuccessful  due 

 
15. 
Capital  Resources.  Upgrading  the  Ring  Road  so  it  is  a  continuously  paved  national 
corridor  by  the  end  of  2008  is  the  goal  for  the  road  sector  set  at  the  London  conference  in 
February  2006.  This  requires  construction  of  a  193-km  road  from  Bala  Murghab  to  Armalik  in 
the  northwestern  region  (see  map).  The  estimated  total  cost  of  constructing  this  road  is  $180 
million. Additionally, to avoid consequences similar to that of the road development programs of 
the  1950s  and  1960s,  approximately  3,100  km  of  roads  are  required  to  complete  the  national 
road  network  and  provide  basic  rural  accessibility.  The  estimated  total  cost  of  that  is  $1.8 
billion.14 About 12,000 km of rural roads and 10,000 km of provincial roads must be improved to 
complete  the  tertiary  road  network,  and  this  will  require  a  further  $1.2  billion  and  raise  total 
funding requirements to $3 billion. The international community has pledged approximately $1 
billion,  but  it  would  be  difficult,  if  not  impossible,  without  donor  assistance  for  Afghanistan  to 
raise the remaining $2 billion needed to provide a minimum nationwide level of mobility. 
 
Operating  Resources.  MPW  and  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  recognize  the 
16. 
importance  of  effective  maintenance,  and  they  are  legally  obligated  under  the  lending 
agreements to maintain newly created road assets. However, efforts to implement a sustainable 
maintenance  program  have  been 
inadequate  planning, 
programming, and funding.  
 
17. 
The  total  annual  cost  of  maintaining  the  regional  road  network  is  expected  to  increase 
from about $6 million in 2007 to approximately $25 million by 2012. As more national roads are 
improved and added to the network, the total length of paved roads is expected to exceed 8,000 
km by 2016, and the corresponding annual funding requirement for maintenance is expected to 
reach $50 million. The estimated total annual cost of maintaining the entire 34,000 km network 
by  that  time  will  reach  $130  million.  At  the  2006  London  conference  Afghanistan  agreed  to 
establish  a  financially  sustainable  road  maintenance  program  by  the  end  of  2007.  However, 
according to the road improvement master plan study (footnote 7), the receipts from road usage 
fees  in  2005  were  about  $3  million,  or  50%  of  the  total  required  funding  for  maintaining  the 
regional network. Therefore, without donor assistance, it will be difficult for Afghanistan to fulfill 
the agreement by the target date.  
 
18. 
Human Resources. In addition to the brain drain of the 1960s, the prolonged closure of 
educational institutions in the 1980s and 1990s has left a vacuum in most public agencies. Even 
since 2002, MPW has been unable to attract qualified staff or persons to be trained in state-of-
the-art road construction and maintenance practices. The primary reason for this is the current 
public  service  pay  structure.  Salaries  of  MPW  engineers  range  from  $60  to  $150  per  month 
while private firms and international agencies offer between $600 and $2000 per month. Other 
employers also provide more on-the-job training in specialized fields, which potential employees 
consider  more  useful  than  the  classroom-type  training  offered  under  technical  assistance 
programs. Consequently, MPW has difficulty executing its functions efficiently.

19.   Planning,  Programming,  and  Monitoring.  Although  in  2006  MPW  established  an 
investment planning unit within its central Planning Department in Kabul, with the exception of 
geometric standards for roads, it has no standards for maintenance works or requirements and 
established  procedures  for  the  planning  unit  to  collect,  compile,  analyze,  and  report  asset 
performance to decision makers and stakeholders. Moreover, the responsibility for programming 
rests  with  provincial  governors,  and  for  payments  it  rests  with  MOF.  In  reality  MPW’s 
responsibility  is  limited  to  designing  capital  and  maintenance  projects  based  on  proposals 
submitted by provincial governors, and helping submit budgets to MOF. International agencies 
have  overcome  some  constraints  by  engaging  private  consulting  firms  and  individuals  to 
supervise projects they fund. However, MPW has been slow in reforming its business process 
and  implementing  an  efficient  program  of  investment  and  maintenance.  Reforms  have  also 
been hampered by human and operating resource constraints.  
 
20. 
Governance.  Due  to  the  urgency  of  restoring  key  components  of  road  infrastructure, 
past stakeholder involvement has been confined to basic consultation with affected persons in 
project impact areas as required by multilateral banks. MPW has limited formal interaction with 
provincial  and  local  administrative  bodies.  There  are  no  mechanisms  for  disseminating 
information on development plans and priorities or for receiving feedback from road users.  
 
21. 
Accounts  of  internationally  funded  projects  are  maintained  independently  by  the 
respective  donors  in  partially  computerized  form  and  audited  according  to  national  and 
international  procedures.  However,  MPW  presently  uses  manual  bookkeeping  procedures  for 
budget-financed operations. This approach undermines the accuracy, transparency, and speed 
of transactions.  
 
22. 
Special  Circumstances.  In  2002, ADB  and  the  international  community  placed  a  high 
priority  on  restoring  basic  transport  services  and  road  infrastructure.  Accordingly,  based  on 
rapid needs assessments and conceptual designs, tenders for works in many cases were called 
on a design-build basis. Similarly, contractors and service providers prepared original bids and 
service  inputs  based  on  limited  or  unreliable  information  on  (i)  geology  and  environment,  (ii) 
availability  and  performance  of 
(iii)  socioeconomic 
characteristics in the impact areas. The consequent potential for design and schedule variations 
had not been fully anticipated by all parties at the time of procurement. Unfortunately, internal 
conflict  has  also  continued  and  global  prices  for  construction  materials  (particularly  bitumen, 
cement,  and  fuel)  have  risen.  When  combined  with  the  scarcity  of  international  and  national 
road builders and consultants with the necessary technical and financial capacity who are willing 
to work in Afghanistan, the conflict and global price rises are creating major financial challenges 
for MPW, contractors, and consultants. 
 
 
 
23. 
Regional.  Although  the  capital-resource  constraint  will  limit  the  rate  at  which  road 
development  can  continue,  Afghanistan’s  commitment  to  adhere  to  the  road  improvement 
master  plan  will  help  maximize  the  impact  of  future  investment.  For  example,  the  master  plan 
outlines  road  investment  priorities  in  relation  to  the  regional  road  corridor  program  linking 
Tajikistan  and  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  and  the  national  trade 
corridor  program  linking  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  with  the  port  of  Karachi  in  Pakistan. 
These  investments  will  expand  the  markets  for  domestic  and  regional  products  and  improve 
road  access  for  Afghanistan’s  landlocked  neighbors  to  seaports  in  Pakistan  and  Iran.  As  was 
the  case  in  the  late  1960s,  this  will  be  an  incentive  for  Afghan  producers  to  increase  their 
production and for authorities to secure more resources for road development.

Development Opportunities 

2. 

 

 

 6 

 

 
24.  MPW  Reforms  and  Private  Sector  Development.  Several  opportunities  exist  for 
easing  the  operating-resource  constraint.  The  most  effective  among  them  in  the  short  term  is 
Afghanistan’s  commitment  to  reform  MPW’s  operating  procedures.  These  reforms  will  replace 
the  present  reactive  force-account  maintenance  procedure  with  a  scientifically  programmed, 
performance-based  procedure.  This  procedure  will  require,  where  appropriate,  (i) 
the 
procurement of works under performance-based contracts with private road builders, (ii) the use 
of new materials and construction practices, and (iii) the auditing of works and services. The first 
requirement, while allowing productivity of force-account resources to be increased and risks to 
be  shared  with  the  private  road  builders,  when  combined  with  the  second  requirement  will 
encourage  innovation  and  the  development  of  local  materials.  Moreover,  outsourcing  all 
construction  and  maintenance  works  will  help  employees  acquire  special  skills  through 
partnerships with the private sector. The United Nations Office for Project Services is engaging 
national  private  contractors  almost  exclusively  on  projects  it  undertakes  on  behalf  of  donors, 
and has a list of contractors ranked on the basis of technical and financial capacity. In the next 
few years these contractors will have the capacity to undertake major road works.  
 
25. 
Donor  Support.  Axle-load  controls  facilitated  by  ADB  through  equipment  and  training 
for  MOTCA  staff  will  lessen  maintenance  requirements.  Moreover,  ADB,  the  World  Bank,  and 
the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) are expected to provide short-
term maintenance budget support to MPW. ADB, under the Project, has allocated $20 million to 
finance 5-year, performance-based contracts for maintaining the 1,100 km of roads which it has 
helped improve since 2002. Similarly, USAID has allocated $33 million for maintaining roads it 
has  helped rehabilitate. While  ADB-funded  maintenance  will  be  procured  through  international 
competitive  bidding  and  supervised  by  competitively  recruited  firms,  a  company  created  and 
managed jointly by MPW staff and international consultants will execute the works financed by 
USAID. This company will absorb all or part of MPW’s workforce and equipment. Additionally, 
the  European  Union  is  presently  financing  an  experimental  performance-based  maintenance 
contract  on  the  Kabul  to  Jalalabad  road,  which  it  helped  rehabilitate.  The  Japan  Bank  for 
International Cooperation has plans to help MPW better utilize its equipment by strengthening 
equipment maintenance capacity. 
 
Public Service Reforms. The ongoing public service reform process, which has already 
26. 
been  implemented  in  some  state  agencies,  will  help  MPW  lessen  the  human-resource 
constraint imposed by salary limits. The reforms also offer a tremendous opportunity to improve 
governance  and  reduce  personnel  needs  by  requiring  MPW  to  use  a  computerized 
management  information  system  (MIS)  for  monitoring  and  reporting  financial  and  asset 
performance to MOF and donors.  
 
27. 
Community Support. The constraints related to security are of the least certain and are 
the  most  binding,  yet  they  are  not  insurmountable  with  more  funds  and  more  involvement  of 
communities  in  project  impact  areas.  The  planned  long-term  road  maintenance  contracts  will 
enable at least some of the local communities to be engaged in road building for several years 
after  the  major  civil  works  are  completed.  Moreover,  the  planned  off-road  service  areas  at 
selected  locations  along  the  key  transit  and  interprovincial  routes  will  serve  as  concentrated 
trading points for local entrepreneurs and will help gather support for the physical components 
of the Project.  
 
Development  Road  Map.  To  enable  Afghanistan  to  meet  these  conditions  and 
28. 
requirements, ADB, in consultation with MOF and MPW, has prepared an investment program 
and road map to guide capital and maintenance investment and MPW  reforms (see Appendix 

 

 

 7 

4). The Project is ADB’s first intervention (Project 1) in the planned pipeline of support for the 
investment program and  roadmap. 
 
29. 
Special  Needs.  There  is  an  urgent  requirement  for  ancillary  and  emergency  works, 
which  include  repairs  and  improvements  to  roads  or  related  infrastructure  due  to  induced 
damages,  damages  due  to  natural  causes,  and  inadequate  preliminary  designs.  The  cost  of 
these works is often high and beyond Afghanistan’s financial capacity to undertake. While these 
types  of  works  normally  would  be  classified  as  supplementary  works  under  ADB’s  policies,  in 
Afghanistan,  a  nontraditional  financing  approach  is  needed  to  meet  urgent  strategic  road 
infrastructure requirements.  
 
30. 
Additional  works  on  210  km  of  road  from  Andkhoy  to  Qaisar  (presently  under 
construction  as  part  of Loan  2140-AFG),15  is  one  activity  which  requires  urgent  financing.  The 
preliminary  alignment  of  this  road,  on  which  estimates  of  cost  of  works  were  based  and 
contractors were awarded, involves changes in elevations of up to 2,200 meters and contains 
gradients  as  high  as  18%.  However,  according  to  the  national  geometric  design  standards 
established  in  2006,  gradients  cannot  exceed  8%,  and  due  to  the  increase  in  Afghanistan’s 
trade with neighboring countries, traffic volumes on the road are expected to exceed forecasts 
made  at  appraisal  in  2004.  Moreover,  during  detailed  surveys  and  designs,  it  has  been 
determined  that  steep  grades  will  severely  hamper  travel  in  the  winter  months  due  to  heavy 
snow  and  rain,  and  research  has  shown  that  the  rate  of  heavy  vehicle  accidents  is  higher  on 
steeper  gradients.16  Therefore,  a  tremendous  opportunity  exists  to  increase  the  benefits  of 
faster journey times under all weather conditions to domestic and international traffic generated 
by  the  Regional  Road  Corridor  Project  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  and  Tajikistan,  and  from  the 
concessions granted at Persian Gulf and Caspian Sea ports for Central Asian exports.

Impact and Outcome 

 
A. 
 
31. 
The  Project  will  contribute  to  the  growth  of  Afghanistan’s  domestic  and  international 
trade.  The  main  outcomes  of  the  Project  will  be  (i)  higher  levels  of  mobility  and  supply  of 
intercity,  interprovincial,  and  international  transport  services;  (ii)  increased  levels  of  service  on 
critical road sections; and (iii) increased service life of the regional road network.

Ancillary and Emergency Works Component 

financed  under  ADB’s  policies  and  procedures 

 
34. 
The  purpose  of  this  component  is  to  allow  rapid  reconstruction  and  rehabilitation  of 
critical road infrastructure that have been damaged due to the continuing conflict or designed at 
suboptimal levels for construction under emergency conditions. It is a cost-effective mechanism 
of  providing  financing  for  uncertain  and  unprogrammed  works.  This  mechanism  will  permit 
works  to  be  undertaken  on  all  roads,  irrespective  of  funding  source.  Although  such  works  on 
for 
ADB  projects  would  normally  be 
supplementary  financing,  the  urgency  and  uncertainty  of  the  extent  of  the  works  that  may  be 
required  calls  for  this  mechanism.  To  be  eligible  for  financing  under  this  component,  the  road 
infrastructure must be: (a) an integral part of a completed or on-going road project financed by 
the  Government,  ADB,  or  other  development  partners;  and/or  (b)  urgently  needed  to  provide 
access  to  strategically  important  areas  or  to  increase  traffic  safety  and  national  technical 
standards.  In  either  case,  they  must  meet  all  of  ADB's  environmental  and  social  safeguard 
requirements.  Works  initially  included  under  this  component  will  be  safety  improvements  in 
various sections of the Andkhoy–Qaisar road, financed from Loan 2140-AFG (footnote 13), by 
reducing  the  vertical  grades  from  14%  to  8%  or  less  to  meet  national  and  regional  geometric 
design  standards  for  two-lane  regional  roads.  Preliminary  works  on  the  Andkhoy–Qaisar  road 
commenced  in  October  2006.  MPW  has  recently  approved  the  required  additional  works  as 
identified  by  the  contractor  and  construction  supervision  firm,  and  when  finalized  it  will  be 
reviewed  and  approved  by  ADB.  No  social  or  environmental  impacts  that  require  further 
assessments  or  mitigating  measures  are  expected.  Other  works  to  be  included  in  this 
component will be appraised and approved by ADB during implementation of the Project.

4.  

 

Business Process Development Component  

 
36. 
The main objective of this component is to increase the sustainability of investment by 
enabling  MPW  to  execute  its  mandated  functions  more  efficiently.  Activities  under  this 
component will build upon the progress made through previous technical assistance from ADB 
and other donors to MPW for capacity building. Activities will include (i) project support through 
specialists on maintenance contract administration, bridge and pavement management, right-of-
way  preservation,  and  environmental  management;  and  (ii)  implementation  of  an  MIS.  While 
specialists working with MPW staff will facilitate knowledge and technology transfer, the MIS will 
facilitate  (i)  investment  planning,  programming,  and  monitoring;  (ii)  financial  management  and 
control; and (iii) contractor evaluation and registration. The MIS  will be a simple computerized 
system for storing and analyzing information on all road assets, including date of construction, 
location,  physical  condition,  level  of  usage,  preservation  history,  and  contractor  and  designer 
details.  It  will  be  designed,  installed,  and  made  operational  in  stages  with  the  objective  of 
eventually creating a countrywide system linking MPW’s head office with its regional offices and 
key line ministries.

45. 
Consultant Selection Methods. The continuing conflict in Afghanistan creates unusual 
conditions  in  which  consultants  must  use  unconventional  approaches  to  reach  project  sites, 
conduct  tests,  supervise  works,  attract  and  retain  qualified  staff,  and  engage  experts  with 
special  skills.  The  assignments  are  therefore  likely  to  be  carried  out  in  substantially  different 
ways  and  consultant's  technical  and  financial  proposals  may  not  be  directly  comparable. 
Further, in the previous projects, consultants have had difficulty using such methods, mobilizing 
national  and  international  specialists  on  a  timely  basis,  maintaining  close  supervision  of 
construction  works,  and  advising  MPW  on  urgent  issues.  These  weaknesses  caused  by  the 
country's  special  security  situation  have  contributed  in  part  to  the  cost  overruns  and 
implementation delays. Considering that the construction supervision has a high impact on the 
community, environment, and project sustainability and will incur a high cost if it fails, the quality 
of the consulting services is more important than the cost and it is appropriate to select the best 
experts available. Therefore, the consultants will be selected and engaged in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time), using the 
quality-based selection (QBS) method as outlined in the procurement plan in Appendix 8. The 
procurement plan will be updated at least annually covering the next 18 months of procurement 
activity.  MPW  will  (i)  prepare  the  requests  for  proposal  (RFP)  using  ADB's  standard  template;

4. 
 

Procurement of Goods and Works 

49.  Methods of Procurement. All procurement activities will be undertaken in accordance 
with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time),  and  the 
procurement  plan  is  given  in  Appendix  8.  The  procurement  plan  will  be  updated  at  least 
annually  covering  the  next  18  months  of  procurement  activity.  Equipment  costing  up  to 
$100,000 will be procured using shopping procedures acceptable to ADB. Works financed from 
the  grant  may  include  (i)  construction,  rehabilitation,  and  repair  of  roads  or  road-related 
infrastructure;  and  (ii)  performance-based  maintenance,  and  will  be  procured  using  ADB’s 
international competitive bidding (ICB) procedures.  
 
50. 
Bidding  Documents.  ADB’s  standard  bidding  documents  will  be  used  for  procuring 
works  for  construction,  rehabilitation,  and  repair  of  roads  or  road-related  infrastructure.  They 
will,  to  the  extent  possible,  contain  performance  criteria  and  security  assurances  that  will 
increase  efficiency  and  the  timely  completion  of  works.  Bidding  documents  for  maintenance 
works, which will be a hybrid of input (bills of quantity based) and output (performance-based),

ensure  consistency  with  the  Procurement  Guidelines,  and  Afghanistan  Procurement  Law

(NCB) procedures, ADB and the Recipient will review the Recipient's procurement procedures 
to ensure consistency with ADB requirements. Any  necessary modifications or clarifications to 
the Recipient's procedures will be documented in the procurement plan.

procured by MPW under three separate design-build contracts using ICB procedures.

53. 
Special Procurement Condition.  The Project is located in an area where countries that 
are not ADB members could provide materials, especially bitumen, fuel, and cement, at highly 
competitive prices. Explicit procurement restrictions may preclude civil works and maintenance 
contractors  from  seeking  the  best  business  terms  from  suppliers  in  these  countries  and 
submitting  competitive  bids.  To  keep  the  project  costs  to  a  minimum,  Management  proposes 
that  works  contractors  financed  from  the  project  be  allowed  to  procure  from  any  country, 
including from countries that are not ADB members, bitumen, fuel and cement, strictly for use in 
the  Project.  ADB’s  Procurement  Committees  in  three  previous  road  development  projects  in 
Afghanistan  approved  this  special  condition.  ADB  and  MPW,  through  routine  reviews  and 
procurement audits, will ensure strict adherence by the contractors to this special condition.  
 

5. 

Advance Contracting and Retroactive Financing  

 
To expedite the bidding process, ADB management has, in principle, approved advance 
54. 
contracting and retroactive financing from the  grant for expenditure incurred on eligible works, 
goods,  and  consulting  services.  Advance  contracting  allows  MPW  to  commence  procurement 
activities, at its own risk, prior to signing of the financing agreement. Afghanistan was informed 
that,  in  order  for  expenses  incurred  under  advance  contracting  to  be  eligible  for  retroactive 
financing,  such  procedures  (including  advertising)  must  comply  with  the  Procurement 
Guidelines and Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. Once the grant becomes effective, up to 
20% of such grant proceeds may be used to retroactively finance eligible expenditures incurred, 
pursuant to advance contracting, during the period not exceeding 12 months prior to signing of 
the  financing  agreement.  Alternatively,  the  Government  may  also  opt  for  advance  contracting 
without  retroactive  financing,  in  which  case  the  procurement  procedures  completed  under 
advance  contracting  do  not  conclude  with  the  award  of  contract  until  after  the  grant  becomes 
effective.  Afghanistan  acknowledges  that  any  concurrence  by  ADB  with  the  procedures, 
documentation, or proposal for award does not commit ADB to finance such expenses. 
 

6. 

Anticorruption Measures  

 
55. 
In accordance with international best practices, MPW and the PMU maintain oversight of 
externally  funded  projects.  The  national  procurement  law  has  several  key  safeguards  and 
clearly  specifies  the  accepted  conduct  of  public  officials  in  matters  of  conflict  of  interest. 
Methods  of  procurement  for  externally  financed  activities,  including ADB’s  projects,  follow  the 
required  procedures  and  guidelines.  Procurement  of  works  and  services  for  budget-financed 
projects is based on the national procurement law. However, there is no formal record keeping, 
evaluation  of  contractor  and  consultant  performance,  or  conflict-of-interest  disclosure  by 
procurement  committee  members  and  bidders.  Site  reviews  by  MPW  and  the  PMU  are 
inadequate. As part of its business process improvements, MPW will establish eligibility criteria 
for persons serving on bid evaluation committees and require disclosure of conflicts of interest.

IV.  

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

 

 
A. 
 

Economic Benefits 

1. 

Construction Component 

 
64. 
After  the  Bala  Murghab–Leman  road  is  completed,  the  overall  travel  time  between  the 
northeast  and  southwest  of  Afghanistan  will  be  reduced  by  3–5  hours,  allowing  people  and 
goods  to  move  faster  and  less  expensively.  It  will  also  cause  vehicle  operating  costs  to  drop 
substantially.  Traffic  on  the  road,  including  traffic  generated  due  to  the  faster  access  offered 
from Central Asia to Persian Gulf and Caspian Sea ports, is expected to grow at 12–15% per 
annum.  
 

 

 

 16 

 

The  estimated  total  (discounted)  benefits23  of  the  road  over  its  15-year  service  life, 
65. 
computed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects  (1997),24  is 
$130  million.  The  distributive  analysis  of  benefits  has  shown  that  (i)  about  21%  of  the  vehicle 
operating cost savings will accrue to car and light-commercial vehicle operators who provide the 
bulk of passenger services, (ii) about 68% will accrue to freight service operators, and (iii) about 
11%  will  accrue  to  bus  operators.  Of  the  travel  time  savings,  nearly  83%  would  accrue  to 
passengers and the rest to shippers of goods. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of the 
road is 19% and the net present value (NPV) is $39 million25.  

The  above  estimates  are  based  on  the  assumptions  that  (i)  at  least  the  regional  road 
66. 
network will be maintained in a good condition, (ii) MOTCA will reform road user charges and 
licensing  procedures,  (iii)  vehicles  from  all  neighboring  countries  will  be  allowed  to  transit 
through Afghanistan, (iv) there will be timely construction of the 50-km Leman–Armalik section 
to complete the Ring Road, and (v) investment in other sectors continues. The sensitivity of the 
economic  viability  of  the  investment  to  these  assumptions  was  tested  computing  EIRRs  (i)  at 
higher costs, (ii) at lower traffic volumes, and (iii) with both of these conditions. Sensitivity test 
results shown in Table 3 suggest that EIRR and NPV values remain robust, even in the case of 
traffic  volumes  being  50%  less  than  the  base  case  in  the  initial  5  years  as  a  result  of  the 
Leman–Armalik  road  construction  being  delayed  in  the  absence  of  timely  financing  from  the 
Islamic  Development  Bank  and  Saudi  Fund.  It  is  assumed  that,  regardless  of  the  funding 
source,  the  road  will  be  constructed  within  the  5  years  and  traffic  would  increase  at  the  base 
rate in the subsequent 5 years.

EIRR  will  be  greater  than  17%.  Details  of  the  economic  analysis  are  given  in  Supplementary

3. 

Maintenance Component 

Environmental Impacts  

 
69. 
The  average  service  life  of  an  asphalt  concrete  road  is  15  years  or  more.  However,  in 
the absence of routine maintenance, serviceability drops rapidly, causing travel time and vehicle 
operating cost savings to diminish within 3 years. The life of the pavement can drop to 8 years. 
For  instance,  the  $74  million  NPV  of  the  benefits  and  the  40%  EIRR  of  the  $56  million 
investment in the 219-km section from Phule Kumri through Naibabad to Hairatan,27 without any 
maintenance would drop to an NPV of $1 million and an EIRR of 13%. However, an investment 
of $51 million, or an average of $3.5 million per year ($16,000 per km per year) in maintenance 
will sustain the benefits over the life of the road. The maintenance component of the Project is, 
therefore,  aimed  at  helping  Afghanistan  make  timely  maintenance  investments  in  order  to 
preserve approximately 1,000 km of roads created with financing from ADB since 2004.  
 
B. 
 
70. 
Based  on  the  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  conducted  in  accordance  with 
ADB’s Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003)28 during preparation, the Project has been 
classified according to ADB’s Environment Policy (2002) as category B. A summary of the IEE 
of the Bala Murghab to Leman road is provided in Supplementary Appendix G. Given that civil 
works in the Project will be procured under design-build contract, an environment management 
plan  will  be  prepared  during  detailed  design  of  the  road.  The  plan  will  define  measures  to 
mitigate  the  minimal  short-term  environmental  impacts  expected  from  related  civil  works  and 
maintenance.  Sufficient  funding  has  been  allocated  for  mitigating  potential  short-term  impacts. 
MPW will monitor implementation of environmental management plans through its own staff and 
supervision  consultants,  and  report  to ADB  on  a  quarterly  basis.  Potential  long-term  negative 
environmental  impacts  (including  changes  in  land-use,  emission  levels,  and  natural  resources 
usage) due to the Project will be addressed during implementation.  
 
C. 
 
71. 
In accordance with ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995), MPW has prepared a 
draft  resettlement  plan  for  the  strategically  and  economically  important  Bala  Murghab–Leman 
road,  and  disclosed  this  to  persons  that  are  likely  to  be  affected,  some  of  who  have  migrated 
into the area since then due to the continuing conflict in adjacent areas. The resettlement plan 
(summary in Appendix 9) does not fully meet the requirements of ADB’s policy, partially due to 
incomplete data on affected persons, which was difficult to gather due to some security related 
restrictions in Bala Murghab area.  Moreover, impacts cannot be fully ascertained until the final 
alignment  of  the  road  is  established. This  situation  has  arisen  because  construction  works  on 
the road have to be procured on a design-build basis to expedite completion. The design-build 
method  allows  contractors  to  undertake  unobtrusive  preconstruction  works  while  detailed 
designs  are  prepared.  Accordingly,  as  detailed  design  progresses,  MPW  will  gather  specific 
socioeconomic  data,  update  the  resettlement  plan  (given  in  Supplementary Appendix  H),  and 
take  all  actions  sequentially  outlined  therein  to  ensure  complete  adherence  to  ADB’s

Social and Poverty Impacts  

resettlement  policy  and  national  safeguard  requirements.  The  updated  resettlement  plan  will 
specify sections of the road where land acquisition and resettlement are required. ADB will work 
with MPW to ensure that (i) all compensation is paid before land acquisition and demolition of 
property occurs, and (ii) MPW’s contracts with the design and construction firms contain specific 
clauses precluding commencement of physical works in sections with resettlement impacts until 
all key resettlement activities are completed. The supervision consultants’ contracts will contain 
specific  monitoring  provisions,  including  (i)  retaining  resettlement  specialists  in  the  team,  (ii) 
ensuring  that  contractors  comply  fully  with  the  legal  and  policy  requirements,  and  (iii)  that  the 
contractors’  work  programs  are  not  approved  unless  schedules  allow  adequate  time  for 
resettlement  activities  to  be  completed. Adequate  funds  for  land  acquisition  and  resettlement 
are defined in the project budget.  
 
D. 
 
72. 
An  assessment  of  impact  of  the  Project  on  indigenous  peoples  has  been  performed  in 
accordance with ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998). It has been found that the there 
are no indigenous peoples in the project influence zone and that the Project in general will not 
have an impact on indigenous peoples. The Project is accordingly classified as category C. 
 
73. 
A  poverty  and  social  analysis  of  the  Project  has  been  conducted  in  accordance  with 
ADB’s Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis (2001).29 It has shown that the road will create 
direct business and employment opportunities for the local communities in the project influence 
areas.  Initially,  employment  opportunities  will  be  in  the  road  construction  industry,  which  will 
require input of approximately 1,100 person-years of unskilled local labor and 675 person-years 
of  skilled  labor.  Based  on  ongoing  road  projects,  about  80%  of  the  unskilled  labor  can  be 
expected to be sourced from the local communities. Moreover, with its funds ADB is proposing 
the  award  of  3–5  year  contracts  to  the  private  sector  for  maintaining  the  completed  regional 
roads.  These  contracts,  which  are  for  daily  preventative  maintenance,  will  lead  to  longer-term 
employment  opportunities. There  are  also  off-road  service  and  rest  areas  planned  at  strategic 
locations  along  the  road,  which  will  offer  excellent  opportunities  for  local  farmers  and  crafts 
people  for  trade  and  the  provision  of  services  such  as  food  sales  and  vehicle  care.  MPW  will 
engage  observers  to  monitor  implementation  of  the  poverty  reduction  and  social  strategy,  and 
results will be included in MPW’s quarterly progress reports to ADB. A summary of the poverty 
reduction and social strategy for the Project is in Appendix 10.  
 
E. 
 
74. 
There  is  a  risk  of  the  continuing  conflict  causing  project  costs  to  rise  because  of  the 
limited  pool  of  contractors  and  consultants  willing  and  able  to  work  in  Afghanistan.  There  is 
evidence  from  ongoing  road  projects  that  contract  prices  in  the  past  2  years  have  risen  over 
20%  due  to  (i)  higher  materials  prices,  (ii)  additional  security  required  for  contractor  and 
consultant  staff  and  equipment,  and  (iii)  work  interruptions.  Additionally,  there  is  a  risk  of 
damage  to  physical  assets  that  arises  from  the  continuing  conflict,  which  impedes  trade  and 
travel, and in turn economic growth. However, the potential for engaging the local communities 
in  construction  and  maintenance  of  the  roads  and  the  provision  of  local  trading  facilities  is 
expected to generate community support for the Project, and this may serve as a deterrent to 
those seeking to cause property damage. Even if not completely avoided, the repair of conflict-
induced damage (if not extensive), will be less costly and faster under the performance-based 
maintenance contracts.

TRANSPORT SECTOR ASSESSMENT 

Overview  

A. 
 
The  Afghanistan  transport  sector  comprises  road,  rail,  air,  and  waterway 
1. 
transport  services  and  infrastructure.  At  the  beginning  of  2002  more  than  70%  of  the 
transport  network  had  been  damaged  from  conflict  and  neglect  over  the  past  two 
decades,  but  infrastructure  is  now  being  reconstructed  and  services  reintroduced 
through  the  joint  efforts  of  the  Government,  external  donors,  and  the  private  sector. 
Significant progress has been made to restore basic road and air transport services but 
large  areas  of  the  country  remain  inaccessible  and  the  majority  of  roads  are  unpaved 
and in poor condition.  
 
As determined by the road improvement master plan study undertaken in 2005,30 
2. 
there  are  approximately  38,500  kilometers  (km)  of  roads  divided  into  3,300  km  of 
regional  highways,31  4,700  km  of  national  highways,  9,700  km  of  provincial  roads, 
17,000  km  of  rural  roads,  and  3,800  km  of  urban  roads.  Since  2002,  almost  2,100  km 
(63%)  of  regional  highways,  650  km  (14%)  of  national  highways,  and  6,000  km  of 
provincial or rural roads have been reconstructed. Work is underway on (or funding has 
been obtained for) the remaining regional highways, except for a 193-km section east of 
heart.32 Funding has been obtained for reconstruction of a further 1,800 km of national 
highways  and  3,000  km  of  provincial  and  rural  roads,  but  it  will  take  10–20  years  to 
improve the remainder of the national highway and provincial road network.33  
 
The  Ministry  of  Public  Works  (MPW)  is  responsible  for  the  planning,  design, 
3. 
construction,  and  maintenance  of  the  regional  and  national  highways  and  provincial 
roads.  It  has  a  workforce  of  approximately  900  engineers  and  administrative  staff  and 
2,000  departmental  laborers.  It  has  eight  regional  maintenance  centers,  each  serving 
four  or  more  provinces,  and  a  district  maintenance  office  in  each  of  the  34  provinces. 
Road investment is almost entirely financed by international development agencies with 
varied  procurement  and  implementation  arrangements.  MPW  has  assumed  the  role  of 
administrator of the investment program.  
 
4. 
The  Ministry  of  Transport  and  Civil  Aviation  (MOTCA)  is  responsible  for  the 
regulation  of  transport  operators  and  services  as  well  as  for  providing  passenger  and 
freight  road  transport  services  with  government-owned  vehicles.  Previous  legislation 
authorized the Government to provide nationwide freight and passenger services, and in 
1990  MOTCA  reportedly  controlled  16,000  trucks,  12,000  buses,  and  extensive 
workshops. Today MOTCA has approximately 1,180 staff and its current functions in the 
road  transport  sector  include  (i)  the  regulation  of  privately  owned  commercial  vehicles; 
(ii)  vehicle  registration,  renewal,  and  inspection;  (iii)  collection  of  the  Transport

5. 
Nearly  95%  of  national  and  international  passenger  and  freight  traffic  is  road-
based. In 2005, vehicle registrations included 207,000 private cars, 55,000 taxis, 42,000 
buses,34  110,900  trucks  and  more  than  400,000  motorcycles.  Vehicle  numbers  are 
increasing  rapidly,  with  annual  growth  over  the  past  3  years  of  22%  for  cars,  15%  for 
trucks, 18% for motorcycles, but only 2% for buses. Virtually all vehicles are secondhand 
imports from Japan and Europe.  
 
6. 
 MOTCA has registered 165 private bus companies (101 based in Kabul and 64 
in  the  provinces)  with  a  fleet  of  14,000  buses  which  operate  intercity  services  on  the 
regional and national highways. The remaining buses are 8- to 12-seater vans owned by 
individuals providing informal passenger transport services in the cities and connections 
between rural areas and towns. The only cross-border bus service is between Jalalabad 
and Peshawar (Pakistan). MOTCA reports that 45 million passenger trips were made by 
bus  transport  in  2005.  Fares  are  estimated  to  be  $0.012  per  km  for  paved  roads  and 
$0.016  per  km  for  unpaved  roads.  Operators  pay  a  3%  commission  to  MOTCA  at 
provincial or national borders and at the outskirts of major towns. 
 
Freight is carried primarily in privately owned trucks. Traffic counts show that the 
7. 
composition  of  truck  numbers  is  approximately  20%  heavy  articulated  trucks  with  the 
remaining  80%  divided  more  or  less  equally  into  heavy,  medium,  and  light  (or  pickup) 
classes.  Freight  charges  are  approximately  $0.16  per  ton  per  km  on  paved  roads  and 
$0.21 to $0.35 per ton per km on unpaved roads. A 5% commission per trip is charged 
by MOTCA. There are no special transit charges and foreign trucks transporting freight 
though Afghanistan are charged the 5% commission only. 
 
In addition to its role in road transport, MOTCA operates two international and 22

reiterated in the Afghanistan Compact,37 by the end of 2010 Kabul International Airport 
and  Herat  Airport  will  achieve  full  international  ICAO  compliance;  Mazar-i-Sharif, 
Jalalabad  and  Kandahar  will  be  upgraded  with  runway  repairs  and  air  navigation, 
rescue,  firefighting,  and  communications  equipment.  Another  seven  domestic  airports 
will  be  upgraded  to  facilitate  domestic  air  services.  Kabul  International  Airport  handled 
approximately 500,000 international and domestic passengers in 2005.

several  Asian  destinations  are  currently  provided  by  Ariana,  Kam  Air  and  international

Rail  services  are  operated  to  railway  yards  a  few  km  inside  Afghanistan  at

railway  yards  are  operated  by  the  Ministry  of  Commerce  and  provide  storage  and

trains  per  day  with  30  wagons  each,  the  equivalent  of  approximately  157  trucks, 
compared  with  transborder  road  traffic  of  approximately  33  trucks  per  day.  Traffic  at 
Torghundi  is  two  trains  per  day  with  20–25  wagons  each.  The  majority  of  imports  is 
petroleum products, humanitarian food-aid and, at Torghundi, scrap metal transshipped 
by truck to Pakistan. There is very little reverse traffic other than some seasonal fruit. 
 
River  transport  once  thrived  on  the  Amu  Darya  and  its  tributaries.38  Today,  an 
11.

with a capacity of 4–5 trucks a few times per day depending on traffic. The United States 
Agency  for  International  Development  (USAID)  is  funding  a  road  bridge  across  the 
Pyanzh  River  closer  to  Sirkhan  Bandar,  and  this  will  be  completed  in  2007.  The  traffic 
potential  through  this  border  crossing  is  significant  and  plans  are  being  made  for  full 
border facilities. 
 
Afghanistan  currently  has  eight  formal  border  points.39  The  roads  connecting

Afghanistan. Already there is significant traffic as measured by the average daily number 
of  trucks  crossing  at  border  points,  for  example:40  Torkham  1,100,  Spin  Boldak  385,

through  existing  projects.  MPW  has  established  priorities  for  reconstructing  the

the  road 
Supplementary Appendix C.  
 
15. 
The  17,000  km  of  rural  roads  are  the  responsibility  of  the  Ministry  of  Rural 
Rehabilitation  and  Development  (MRRD).  MRRD  has  received  assistance  from  a 
number of donors and has improved 6,000 km of road, though much of the work was in 
the  form  of  temporary  repairs  under  emergency  employment  schemes.  MRRD  has 
established a planning process and has commenced preparing rural road improvement 
plans  and  programs  on  a  district-by-district  basis.  In  contrast,  MPW  has  not  carried 
forward  the  provincial  road  priorities  recommended  by  the  road  improvement  master 
plan and has not established a development program for the provincial roads.  
 
C. 
 
16.  MPW’s focus has been on project implementation and its most skilled engineers 
have  been  seconded  to  work  on  donor-funded  projects.  Strategic  planning,  budgeting 
and  programming,  road  network  condition  monitoring,  maintenance  management,  road 
safety,  and  enforcement  of  traffic  and  vehicle  regulations,  have  been  neglected. 
Technical  assistance  to  build  capacity  is  being  provided  by  several  donors  including 
ADB41 but further capacity building is needed in key areas.   
 
17.  MPW’s annual budget for road maintenance works (excluding employee salaries) 
in  the  past  3  years  has  varied  between  $4  million  and  $8  million,  compared  with  an 
estimated  minimum  requirement  of  $15  million  for  the  present  network.  This  figure  will 
increase  to  approximately  $70  million  per  year  in  the  next  5–10  years  when  periodic 
maintenance of improved roads will become a major requirement. 
  
18.  MPW’s  capacity  to  undertake  road  maintenance  is  limited  by  (i)  a  lack  of 
transport,  equipment,  and  tools  to  carry  out  the  work;  (ii)  the  absence  of  a  road 
maintenance  management  system  to  assess  needs,  estimate  costs,  program  works, 
monitor  progress,  and  report  results;  and  (iii)  the  absence  of  a  contract  administration 
system  for  efficient  procurement,  quality  management,  measurement,  and  payment. 
MPW  has  purchased  some  new  equipment  and  the  Japan  International  Cooperation 
Agency is funding the rehabilitation of the machinery repair centre in Kabul and providing 
training in equipment operation and maintenance. Apart from this assistance, there is a 
consensus among  the  external  donors  that  MPW  should adopt  contracting  with private 
contractors  and  community  groups  as  the  principal  method  for  delivering  maintenance 
and  limit  its  role  to  managing  maintenance  and  providing  an  emergency  maintenance 
capacity  at  most.  The  European  Union  has  implemented  a  pilot  contract  maintenance 
project  on  the  improved  Surobi–Jalalabad  road.  The  World  Bank  is  funding  pilot 
maintenance  projects  on  rural  roads  using  community-based  labor  groups.  USAID  is 
preparing  a  technical  assistance  project  to  build  a  contract  maintenance  capacity  in

20. 
International contractors, principally from India, Iran, Pakistan, People’s Republic 
of  China,  Republic  of  Korea,  and  Turkey,  have  been  employed  for  the  major  highway 
projects. Domestic contractors have obtained subcontract work and are being employed 
directly  in  rural  road  construction  funded  by  USAID  and  the  World  Bank.  The  United 
Nations  Office  for  Project  Services  has  a  register  of  23  qualified  domestic  contractors 
which it employs regularly. There is a need to expand the domestic industry’s capacity 
for  maintenance  work  and  for  small-  and  medium-sized  road  and  bridge  construction 
projects which are expected to form a major source of work after the large road projects 
are completed. The outlook is promising but further support for the domestic industry is 
needed in the form of (i) availability of contracts, (ii) transparent procurement processes, 
(iii)  reasonable  technical  and  financial  qualification  requirements,  (iv)  practical  and 
achievable  technical  specifications  for  works,  and  (v)  on-time  payment  for  completed 
work.  
 
21. 
There is a shortage of qualified engineers and technicians for road and structural 
design  and  construction  supervision,  and  this  is  being  filled  by  extensive  use  of 
international  consulting  companies  and  contract  staff.  This  is  a  temporary  condition 
created by the aftermath of conflict and the rapid build-up of road construction work. In 
the  longer  term,  the  Government  and  private  sector  will  require  a  corps  of  domestic

the 

three  simultaneous  design-build  contracts.  Accordingly, 

 
1. 
The Road Network Development Project 1 comprises four components: (i) construction, 
(ii)  ancillary  and  emergency  works,  (iii)  maintenance,  and  (iv)  business  process  development. 
The main output of the first component is a 143-km two-lane road from Bala Murghab to Leman, 
which  is  one  of  the  two  critical  missing  links  of  the  Ring  Road.  Traffic  between  Bala  Murghab 
and  Leman  presently  uses  several  dirt  tracks,  some  of  which  pass  through  three  local 
communities.  
 
For  reasons  of  expediency  and  urgency  to  meet  Afghanistan  Compact1  targets,  the 
2. 
Ministry  of  Public  Works  (MPW)  will  procure  civil  works  on  the  Bala  Murghab–Leman  road 
through 
final  and  most 
economically,  socially,  and  environmentally  viable  alignment  will  be  determined  by  MPW  (the 
Executing Agency of the Project) after detailed field surveys are completed by the contractors. 
Until the alignment is finalized, the exact extent of the impact of the road on people, land, and 
built  structures  cannot  be  determined.  Consequently,  a  full  resettlement  plan,  which  fulfils  all 
requirements of ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement (1995), could not be prepared.  
 
3. 
Under the circumstances, to enable civil works contracts to be awarded so that detailed 
designs  could  be  completed  and  a  resettlement  plan  prepared,  MPW  has  prepared  this  draft 
resettlement plan for the Bala Murghab–Leman road section. It served as the basis for project 
appraisal  and  determination  of  the  conditions  for  commencing  construction.  The  draft 
resettlement  plan  is  based  on  the  initial  surveys  performed  under  TA  4875-AFG,  and  is  in 
accordance  with  the  Policy  on  Involuntary  Resettlement  as  well  as  the  domestic  policy 
instruments and laws, particularly the provisions made under the Law on Land Acquisition in the 
constitution of Afghanistan. It reports the likely impact on people, land, and structures if the road 
follows the dirt track, which is presently the most frequently used route.  
 
4. 
The draft resettlement plan has been prepared in due consultation with those who have 
a high likelihood of being categorized as affected families and affected persons if the alignment 
follows  the  present  track.  It  is  intended  to  be  a  guide  for  MPW  staff,  construction  supervision 
consultants,  and  civil  works  contractors  on  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  procedures, 
including the payment of adequate and timely compensation for individuals or groups that may 
be affected by the construction.

persons will be supported and used, (v) land acquisition provisions will equally apply to women

Contribution of the sector to reduce poverty in Afghanistan: 
 
The  proposed  Road  Network  Development  Project  1  supports  regional  road  development  by  (i) 
constructing a section of the Afghanistan Ring Road, (ii) serving the country by creating a potentially highly 
economically beneficial thoroughfare linking it both domestically and internationally, and (iii) contributing to 
the social and economic development in this region of Afghanistan by facilitating the increased mobility and 
accessibility  of  people  and  goods  across  Afghanistan.  Agriculture  and  other  rural-based  activities  are  the 
mainstay of the Afghan economy, and the proposed Project will contribute to poverty reduction by providing 
access  to  urban  markets  for  agricultural  products.  The  Project  will  also  improve  rural  peoples’  access  to 
education and health facilities. 

 
B. Poverty Analysis                                    Targeting Classification: General intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
Afghanistan is one of the poorest countries in the world.1  Poverty, caused by years of war, is pervasive. 
The  legacy  of  poverty,  violence,  and  war  is  that  the  majority  of  Afghans  are  Socially  and  politically 
insecure.  Approximately 53% of the population is classified as poor and lives on less than $1 a day.2 The 
average  life  expectancy  at  birth  is  43  years  (20  years  lower  than  in  neighboring  Tajikistan),  child 
malnutrition is 49%, access to an improved water source is 13%, access to improved sanitation facilities is 
12%, the fertility rate is 6.8 live-births per woman, and malnourishment is at 70%. Afghanistan’s economy 
continues to be overwhelmingly agricultural, despite the fact that only 12% of its total land area is arable, 
and  less  than  6%  is  currently  cultivated.3  Agricultural  production  is  constrained  by  an  almost  total 
dependence on erratic winter snows and spring rains for water; irrigation is primitive. Relatively little use is 
made  of  machines,  chemical  fertilizers,  or  pesticides.  Overall  agricultural  production  has  declined 
dramatically  following  severe  drought  as  well  as  sustained  fighting,  instability  in  rural  areas,  and 
deteriorated infrastructure. A study based primarily on the Nationwide Risk and Vulnerability Assessment 
Sample Survey 2005, along with public consultations, was undertaken to gather qualitative information on 
the social and poverty scenario for the influence areas of the Project. 
 
C. Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?                 X Yes         X No 
 
In  order  to  ensure  the  extensive  participation  of  all  types  of  stakeholders  during  project  preparation, 
discussions were held with citizens, poor people, affected persons, and other beneficiaries, local bodies, 
and  government  departments  through  consultative  workshops,  meetings,  focus-group  discussions,  and 
structured  interviews.  The  Executing  Agency  (EA)  undertook  consultations  with  local  officials,  villagers, 
and  other  stakeholders  that  raised  the  level  of  awareness,  built  local  support,  and  enabled  affected 
people  to  voice  opinions  and  suggestions  for  project  design  and  implementation.  Household  census 
surveys  were  conducted  where  security  threats  were  low.  Participation,  consultation,  and  information 
dissemination was incorporated at several levels during planning of the Project. To ensure that community 
support is obtained and that the Project supports the felt needs of the people, public consultations were 
carried out as an integral component of project preparation.

Development Strategy)

Appendix 10 

 

 

  
Is there a participation strategy?                  X Yes         X No 
 
Public  participation  is  the  key  element  of  the  project  design  during  the  whole  process  of  planning, 
implementation, operation, and maintenance. The proposed broad-based participatory strategy for public 
participation  focuses  on  partnership  between  poor  communities,  community-based  organizations, 
nongovernment organizations, local administrative bodies, and the Government. Extensive consultations 
were undertaken to ensure stakeholder participation in project design. 
 
A  number  of  elements  in  the  Project  also  seek  to  make  the  road  network  development  process  more 
participatory and needs-based. These include provisions to strengthen field offices of the Government so 
that they are more responsive to the felt needs at the local level. Despite logistical and communications 
constraints, the Government is committed to participatory processes. 
 
D. Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women:  
 
Data has been analyzed to assess the status of women in cities in the project’s zone of influence. This 
shows  gender  differences  in  literacy,  employment  status,  and  workload  in  the  family  due  to  absence  of 
basic civic amenities. The strategy of participation emphasizes women’s participation, which is expected 
to maximize the benefits of women. 
 
Monitoring and evaluation systems will consider gender disaggregated information for the assessment of 
the impact of the Project on women. The strategy for women’s participation ensures that women and men 
benefit equally from the Project. Interventions will be introduced to avoid gender bias. Project benefits will 
be ensured for women through gender mainstreaming and a gender responsive participation framework. 
Monitoring  and  evaluation  systems  will  generate  gender-disaggregated  data  to  enable  assessment  of 
gender implications and impact of the Project.
